bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, June 29, 1900

div1.p: Reed requests that Private Tracey be detailed to Havana to help in the animal laboratory, and also requests additional funding for the purchase of more animals. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to George Miller Sternberg, June 29, 1900
div1.opener:
Personal,
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba.
June 29, 1900.
Dear Genl Sternberg:
div1.p:
I am
forwarding by this mail an
application for the Detail
of Private Augustus Tracey,
now on duty at the museum,
for duty with our Board.
If he could be assigned
to duty in Havana by the
order, then he could draw
commutation for rations
& quarters, & I could use
him wherever I liked.
I can find no man here
suitable to look after
animals or laboratories,
and life is too short, when
one is busy, to stop &
train an ignorant man.
I expect to send an order
to Donohue in New York
for more rabbits & pigs
& I want them to come
on the same Transport
with Tracey so that he
can care for them.
I would like for him
to have 10 days or so
in which to arrange
his affairs, as he has
a wife & children to pro-
vide for. He will
not be exposed to any
infection. I find that I
have left remaining # 2300 with
which to buy animals & feed,
and hence would be
glad if you would either
send me a check for
#5000, or place this am't.
to my credit with James
T. Dougherty, 409 West
59th St. New York.
He is the man who sup-
plies animals for the Board
of Health in New York, and
is considered most reliable.
We had an autopsy
this morning on a case
that died on the 8th day.
Agramonte performed it
within 2 hours of death - We
took careful cultures &
inoculated pigs with spleen
& liver pulp & contents of
duodenum. There is
one new case in the per-
son of a supposed immune
female nurse, who nursed
Mrs. Edwards during her
illness.
